Editorial
The Community Approach
Extension workers should read the
new book* on Adult Education, by
Sheats, Jayne, and Spence, with es¬
pecial care because it raises highly im¬
portant questions concerning the role
of university extension. After read¬
ing it we should not lay it aside just
handy for occasional reference but rather
use it for continued discussion of our
problems.
The chief controversy highlighted by
the book is posed by the phrase, "the
community approach.” What of the
contention implied, but not explicitly
stated, that primary groups are good
because they are necessary? It is easy
to forget that the “we” feeling has, a
counterpart in exclusive attitudes to¬
ward "they.”
Here are some illustrations of the
weakness of the local community ap¬
proach:
The growing fear of government les¬
sens the areas of cooperation for the
national community.
How about sectarian interests that re¬
fuse secular cooperation? Some de¬
nominations prohibit exercise of suf¬
frage because the U. S. Constitution
does not recognize Jesus Christ explicitly.
How about the “community of schol¬
ars” admirable in many ways but often
“high brow” in vicious contempt for
those who are not intellectual? What
of the community of scientists who too
often assume that it excludes the social
scientists? Or consider the medical
profession which in the United States
officially repudiates socialized medicine,
defined as something abhorrent, when in
actual fact as well as sociological theory
modern health programs inevitably re¬
quire more varieties of organization to
extend benefits more widely? And
consider the international situation in
which the hysterical fears of East ver¬
sus West produce a neutralism that in
its worst features negates freedom to
learn and freedom to teach?
The book recognizes that there are
at least two kinds of communities (ac¬
tually there are many more) but fails to
stress the fact that the classical formu¬
lation of primary groups recognizes four
(the family, tribe, neighborhood, and
play groups) which often actually stand
in the way of the beneficent secondary
groups and institutions.
Citizens too often protest taxation be¬
cause it lessens private wealth for fam¬
ily and tribe; the neighborhood resists
*See review on page 3
city planning; the state community re¬
sents federal power; the play groups set
their special hobbies before the general
welfare.
The point of this editorial is some¬
what vague but does lead to this ques¬
tion: Can we not realize more fully that
there is one institution, the American
University, that is, or ought to be, least
suspect of exclusive and inimical atti¬
tudes? It is an organization that rec¬
ognizes both the community approach
and the institutional approach; it is it¬
self a community of scholars devoted to
one communal purpose, the creation of
new knowledge and broader understand.-
ing. It is universal in its scope, not
sectional. It is relatively objective, not
biased or exclusive. It is committed to
extension of the best ideas for an ever
widening human whole.
W. S. Bittner
Walt Elder
Walter T. Elder, Bursar and Director
of Students of Rutgers University College
and University Extension Division, died
suddenly of a heart condition at St.
John’s Hospital, Tulsa, Oklahoma, May
21 at 2:10 p.m. Prof. Elder was visit¬
ing his brother Stanley G. Elder of that
city.
Professor Elder was born January 20,
1893, in North Braddock, Pennsylvania.
He was stricken with a heart condition
in early November; his condition was
worsened by his wife Helen’s death a
few days later.
Professor Elder helped organize the
University Extension Division in 1925.
He received an A.B. degree in Mathe¬
matics from Penn State and a M. S. de¬
gree from New York University.
In 1926 he was made Assistant Pro¬
fessor of Industrial Extension at Rut¬
gers. On January 1, 1929, he became Pro¬
fessor of University Extension. F've
years later he was made Assistant Direc¬
tor of University College, which title was
changed to Director of Students of Uni¬
versity College and the University Exten¬
sion Division. He was active in com¬
mittee work for NUEA.
Hawaii
The University of Hawaii Extension
Division offers a considerable number
of courses in agriculture, art, business,
engineering, languages, and special
courses in chemistry, photography, carv¬
ing, psychiatry, and personality adjust¬
ment.
Additional programs are conducted at
Hickman Center (Airmen’s Education)
and the Downtown Center.
A ten-weeks Television Workshop is
scheduled this summer, directed by
Wright Esser, Kona Television Station.
Visual Personnel
Personal and professional information
about individuals with motion picture
production and teaching experience is
being compiled by the University Film
Producers Association through its Per¬
sonnel Committee.
This listing will assist universities and
other employers in exploring personnel
resources that could be used for the
growth and enrichment of their pro¬
grams of audio-visual production and
training. Although most of those per¬
sons who have already submitted per¬
sonal and professional information to the
Committee are members of the U.F.P.A.
and are engaged in university work, non¬
members are also invited to register.
Individuals who wish to send their
personal data and professional qualifica¬
tions to the Committee, as well as pro¬
spective employers who wish to receive
names, addresses, and information con¬
cerning persons who have qualifications
for specified job openings, should write
to the U.F.P.A. Personnel Committee
Chairman, Ledford C. Carter, Audio-
Visual Center, Indiana University,
Bloomington, Indiana. There is no
charge for these services.
Foreign Policy
Indiana University, with the support of
Lilly Endowment,, Inc., will sponsor the
Fourth Conference on Problems of Amer¬
ican Foreign Policy on the Bloomington
campus Friday and Saturday, July 10
and 11, 1953.
The conference will concern itself
this year with the problem presented
by the Soviet Union.
Group Development
The second annual Western Training
Laboratory in Group Development is
scheduled for next August 16 to 28 at
Idyllwild, California, under auspices of
the School of Education and University
Extension on the Los Angeles campus
of the University of California.
CNO
Interviews to collect material for the
survey of adult education in national
organizations represented in the CNO
have been completed. The directory
of organizations and survey of findings
resulting from the study will be avail¬
able during the summer of 1953.
Dr. L. H. Adolfson is chairman of
the Council of National Organizations
of which the NUEA is a member.
Labor Economics
Two courses in Labor Economics are
scheduled at the Gary and East Chi¬
cago Centers, Indiana University, June
22 to August 7: Introduction to Labor
Economics, and Practices and Problems
of Collective Bargaining.
